title: 109_hr1370
content: The Act titled "Federal Land Asset Inventory Reform Act of 2005" establishes a cadastre of federal land. The Secretary will develop a multipurpose cadastre of Federal real property for land management and resource conservation. Cost sharing agreements with States may be made to include non-Federal lands in the cadastre. A report on real property inventories must be submitted to specific committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act authorizes the development of a multipurpose cadastre of Federal real property for land management and resource conservation. A report on existing real property inventories must be submitted within 180 days, including details on expenditures and activities in fiscal year 2004. The cadastre will consolidate certain components authorized by law, with justification for those not included. The Act authorizes the development of a multipurpose cadastre of Federal real property for land management and resource conservation. A report on existing real property inventories must be submitted within 180 days, including details on expenditures and activities in fiscal year 2004. The cadastre will consolidate certain components authorized by law, with justification for those not included, cost savings, and recommendations for legislation to enhance efficiency. Coordination is required for implementation. The Secretary is required to coordinate and participate in establishing standards for interoperability of geospatial information related to the cadastre. This includes coordinating with the Federal Geographic Data Committee and making the cadastre interoperable with the Federal Real Property Profile. Contracts for surveying and mapping services under Executive Order 13327 should be provided by the private sector to develop the cadastre, following selection procedures in accordance with the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this section, the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "cadastre" is defined as an inventory of Federal Government real property developed through collecting, storing, and disseminating data depicting physical features and boundaries of the earth. This includes surveys, maps, satellite data, and services provided by professionals such as surveyors and cartographers. Real property is defined as real estate including land, buildings, crops, forests, and resources attached to the land. It involves a reference frame with a geodetic network, accurate maps, cadastral boundaries, parcel indexing, and land data files containing information on parcel use, value, infrastructure, resources, and characteristics. Real property includes land, improvements, fixtures permanently attached to the land or structures, and any interest, benefit, right, or privilege in such property.
